changestmt.change: Image acquisition, scanning, and metadata creation
changestmt.respstmt: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill Technical Editor: Matt KirschenbaumProject Manager: Andrea LaueProject Assistants: Gwen Kern,Sarah Trippensee

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, colorist

imprint.publisher: There is no imprint for this series of prints as such, but Object 1 retains the 1794 imprint on the title page (Plate 1) of *The First Book of Urizen*. Blake printed *The Small Book of Designs* Copy A on commission for Ozias Humphry in 1796. See the note on Composition Date, below.
imprint.pubplace: LondonThere is no imprint for this series of prints as such, but Object 1 retains the Lambeth imprint on the title page (Plate 1) of *The First Book of Urizen*. Blake was living in London at the time of the composition and etching of the plates assembled into this series of prints; he was also living in London during the printing of *A Small Book of Designs* in 1796.
imprint.date: Object 1 retains the 1794 date on the title page (Plate 1) of *The First Book of Urizen*, but the prints constituting *A Small Book of Designs* were printed in 1796. See the note on Composition Date, below.

objdescid.compdate: 1796*A Small Book of Designs* contains a selection of designs without accompanying texts from Blake's illuminated books produced between 1789 and 1794. In Copy B of *A Small Book of Designs*, the date on the title page (Plate 1) of *The First Book of Urizen* was altered by Blake in pen and ink from 1794 to "1796." Since both copies of *A Small Book of Designs* were clearly produced during the same printing session, 1796 is the probable date of the printing of Copy A and its composition into a series of prints.

objinfo.printdate: 1796See the note on Composition Date, above.
objinfo.objorder: *The First Book of Urizen* Plate 1, *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Plate 11, *The First Book of Urizen* Plate 17, *The Marriage of Heaven and Hell* Plates 16, 14, 20, *The First Book of Urizen* Plates 23, 24, 3, *The Book of Thel* Plate 2, *The First Book of Urizen* Plates 27, 2, 8, 19, 10, *The Book of Thel* Plate 6, *Visions of the Daughters of Albion* Plate 3, *The First Book of Urizen* Plates 7, 11, *Visions of the Daughters of Albion* Plate 10, *The First Book of Urizen* Plate 5, *The Book of Thel* Plates 7, 4Except for the imprint on Object 1 (retained from the title page of *The First Book of Urizen*), Blake printed these plates from his illuminated books without their accompanying texts. Bentley plate numbers are used here unless otherwise stated.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 15.3 x 12.0 cm. and 3.8 x 9.0 cm.
objinfo.leafsize: ranging between 26.0 x 19.1 cm. and 25.7 x 18.1 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching with color printing and additional water colors and pen and ink outlining
objinfo.inkcolor: Object 1 (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 1), or at least its imprint, was printed in yellow ochre ink. All other plates appear to have been color printed without any inking.
objinfo.watermark: 1794 J WhatmanThe watermark appears only in Object 3 (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 17).
objinfo.binding: disbound and mounted on matsFormerly bound, as the stab holes indicate, but perhaps disbound as early as 1846.
objinfo.stabholes: three stab holes 7.2 cm. and 8.8 cm. apart.

provenance.name: British Museum
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Ozias Humphry in 1796; Humphry's son William Upcott, probably by gift as early as 1797, when Humphry's sight failed, or by inheritance in 1810; possibly sold from Upcott's collection, Messrs. Evans auction, London, 15 June 1846, in lot 277 with *America* Copy H and *Europe* Copy D, possibly among the "original drawings" said in the catalogue to be "inserted" in either or both illuminated books (£7.2s.6d. to the dealer R. H. Evans); sold by Evans to the British Museum in 1856.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 1 (title page), Object 1 (Bentley 136.1, Butlin 260.1)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "13a," not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a rigidly symmetrical composition, a fully gowned old man with closed (or sharply downcast) eyes and long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits cross-legged on a large book in the center foreground. Centered behind him is a pair of stone tablets with arched tops, like tombstones. Indeterminate dark forms, perhaps an arching tree, appear above and on both sides of the tablets. Lying on the ground to the man's left and right are two sets of quadrangular stone tablets or books or, alternatively, the ends of a single long tablet, perhaps a coffin lid. The dark background, trees, and tablets taken together suggest a graveyard setting. Beneath Urizen's feet is an open book. The toes of his right foot emerge from his beard to mark his place in the book. Tree roots sprout to left and right in the foreground beneath the book and tablets. Holding a writing instrument in each hand and resting his arms on the tablets to his left and right, Urizen seems to be copying from the book onto the tablets. The instruments may be quills, graphite pencils, or etching needles. Publication information is centered beneath the book. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design along "Which is the Way / The Right or the Left" (Butlin no. 261.1, Erdman page 673).

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long, flowing white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, sits facing forward, legs crossed, on a book. With both hands, a writing instrument in each, he copies from the book onto stone tablets or books to his right and left with his arms resting on the tablets. The toes of his right foot mark his place in the book. His eyes are closed or looking sharply downward.

Indeterminate dark forms, perhaps a tree or trees, form a cave-like arch over the top half of the plate that tightly encloses the tombstone-like tablets behind Urizen. Further color printing in the top left and right corners of the design may be more vegetation or the trunks of trees. Publication information appears between roots that sprout to left and right at the bottom of the plate.
A large open book on the ground provides a platform for Urizen to sit cross-legged on as he copies its text, which is represented by indecipherable marks.
Urizen holds instruments in both hands that may be quill pens, graphite pencils, or etching needles.

A stone tablet, or two tablets one on top of the other, or stacks of books, provides one of the two surfaces on which Urizen writes. There may be only one tablet with its two ends showing. Its position and material suggest a coffin lid of some sort.
A pair of upright tablets resembling tombstones and the tablets of the decalogue sit directly behind Urizen.
The setting altogether suggests a graveyard.

desc.objtitle: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, Plate 11, Object 2 (Bentley 136.2, Butlin 260.2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a sky streaked with colors of dawn that dispel the darkness, (left to right) a human sun rises, a human tree sprouts, and a maternal earth-goddess nurses an infant flower-spirit in a bed of lush vegetation. These identifications are tentative. The sun-goddess may be a flower- goddess; the tree-god may be a plant-god of another sort. The raised area on the right may be a mound or a distant hill or mountain. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design along "Death & Hell / Team with Life" (Butlin no. 261.2, Erdman page 673).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female faces forward, with her head bent back; she may be rising and looking up. Her long hair, spiked and spread, and her arms, raised at 135 degrees, suggest that she personifies the rising sun.

Slight indications of the face of an old man with a long beard and spiky hair standing on end suggests a tree trunk in human form. The face appears just above the base of the tree. The color printing obscures the face in this impression.
The face of an old man with a long beard and spiky hair standing on end suggests a tree trunk in human form.

Looking down at an infant, a female with long hair lies on her right side, her weight supported on her right elbow. Her back is to the viewer and only her left leg is showing. Her right hand rests on (or at least near) the infant. She may personify the earth in which she seems partly buried. She may be the infant's mother.

A nude infant, arms raised and legs spread, faces up towards a nude female. The infant may be looking at and reaching toward the female. It may represent the human form of the flower-like vegetation in which it lies.

A nude infant, arms raised and legs spread, faces up towards a nude female. It may represent the human form of the lush flame-like, flowery vegetation or leaves in which it lies. The blossom- like structure extends in an arc over the heads of the infant and the female.
Horizontal streaks of red in the sky, perhaps seen between stratus clouds, suggest a sunrise or sunset. The rising figure on the right, probably a personification of the sun, suggests a sunrise.
The color printing on the earth below the figures and plants suggests vegetation, perhaps with grass on the left.
The raised area on the right suggests a nearby mound or a distant hill or mountain.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 17, Object 3 (Bentley 136.3, Butlin 260.3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A figure with long (or at least medium length) hair, perhaps Los creating Enitharmon (or Enitharmon herself), bends forward toward the viewer over a large mottled red and black globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. His head is down, making his face invisible and exposing his back to the viewer. He raises his arms at 135 degrees and holds his hands vertically to his head and perhaps over his ears. Nerves, or sinews, or cords of drapery, or perhaps blood in veins stream over the figure's lower back and along what may be his legs on either side of his back. Similar red, cord-like or vein-like forms cascade from the figure's head or upper body and around the globe. The design may depict the "globe of life blood" that "trembled / Branching out into roots" to embody a "female form trembling and pale . . . the first female now separate" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 18, Erdman page 78). Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the plate "Vegetating in fibres of Blood" (private collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: A figure with long (or at least medium length) hair bends forward toward the viewer over a large mottled red and black globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. His head is down, making his face invisible and exposing his back to the viewer. The figure's back is unclothed. He raises his arms at 135 degrees and holds his hands vertically to his head and perhaps over his ears. Nerves, or sinews, or cords of drapery, or perhaps blood in veins stream over the figure's lower back and along what may be his legs on either side of his back. Similar red, cord-like or vein-like forms cascade from the figure's head or upper body and around the globe. He may be Los creating Enitharmon (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 18, Erdman page 78) or Enitharmon herself.

A figure bends forward over a large mottled red and black globe that occupies the bottom half of the design. This may be the "globe of life blood" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 18, Erdman page 78).

desc.objtitle: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, Plate 16, Object 4 (Bentley 136.4, Butlin 260.4)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The first lines of text on the full plate—"The Giants who formed this world into its sensual existence and now seem to live in it in chains" (*The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*" Plate 16, Erdman page 40)—seem to describe the design, which depicts five gowned human figures sitting in severely contracted positions, all crowded into a dark chamber, prison, or cavern. The heads of all except the bearded central figure, who faces out toward the viewer, are down and turned toward the center. Though the limbs of the figures are drawn tightly together as if chained, no chains are in evidence—in line with the sentiment of the text on the full plate that the giants only "seem" (*The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*" Plate 16, Erdman page 40) to live in chains. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design alone "Who shall set / The Prisoners free" (private collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: Five seated figures sit in a dark chamber, prison, or cave. A more lightly colored strip of floor appears below the figures. It is also possible, in this impression, that this is an outdoor scene and the background is simply the night sky.

The gowned (?) figure with curly hair on the far left sits facing toward the center in a severely contracted position with the visible leg drawn up and head down. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (*The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*" Plate 16, Erdman page 40).

The second figure from the left is apparently a young male with curly hair. He is gowned and sits in a severely contracted position with legs drawn up, head down but twisted toward the center, and right foot exposed, crossed in front of his left leg. His eyes are closed or severely lowered. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (*The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*" Plate 16, Erdman page 40).

The old, partly bald, and gowned male figure in the center, the only one of the five facing forward, sits in a severely contracted position, legs drawn up and crossed, right foot exposed. The absence of pupils suggests that he is either blind or has his eyes closed. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (*The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*" Plate 16, Erdman page 40). The design closely resembles Blake's several illustrations of the Ugolino episode in Dante's Divine Comedy, and thus this central figure is compositionally related to (albeit not directly identifiable as) Count Ugolino surrounded by his sons in prison.
The second figure from the right is apparently male; he is gowned and his hair is curly. He sits in a severely contracted posture with his one visible leg drawn up and his head down.

The gowned figure on the far right is probably a male with curly hair. He sits facing the center in a severely contracted position with his one visible leg drawn up and his head down, possibly on his knees. The figure probably represents one of the "Giants who formed the world into its sensual existence" (*The Marriage of Heaven and Hell*" Plate 16, Erdman page 40).

desc.objtitle: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, Plate 14, Object 5 (Bentley 136.5, Butlin 260.5)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gray male body, nude, arms at his sides, extends horizontally across the plate. The color and arrangement suggest that he is dead. Hovering in flames over him is a nude(?), long- haired female (?) figure with her arms raised horizontally. She is at right angles to the male with her head toward the viewer. At least twice Blake color printed the plate, with its text masked (Butlin nos. 260.5, published here, and 261.3). His inscription for the second of these, "a Flaming Sword / Revolving every way" (Erdman 673), relates the design to the so-called covering cherub, or guardian angel, whom God posted to keep humanity away from the Tree of Life after the expulsion from Eden. The top (rotating) figure in the design would then seem to be a personification of the sword-as-angel who is keeping the dead figure below away from the Tree of Life.

component.illusobjdesc: A gray male body, nude, right arm at his sides, extends horizontally across the plate. Color and arrangement suggest that he is dead. His head is bent back and his eyes may be closed. His hair appears to be fairly long and possibly curly; his right foot is prominent.

Hovering in flames over the dead male is a nude(?) female (?) figure with her arms raised horizontally. Her palms face down and the fingers on her right hand may be slightly spread. Her hair is long and drifts to the right in serpentine tendrils suggesting a spiral. She is at right angles to the male with her head toward the viewer. She may represent the so-called covering cherub, the angel whom God assigned to keep humanity away from the Tree of Life after the expulsion from Eden.
The upper figure hovers in flames that lick up from behind the dead male below. The dark area in the top right corner might be smoke.

desc.objtitle: The Marriage of Heaven and Hell, Plate 20, Object 6 (Bentley 136.6, Butlin 260.6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the waves of a tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears as a coiled, scaly serpent with its head raised vertically, mouth open, teeth visible, tongue extended. The sky is reddish on the left (suggesting a sunrise or sunset), dark on the right. Blake inscribed another color-printed impression of the design alone "O revolving Serpent / O the Ocean of Time & Space" (Essick collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: In the waves of a tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears as a coiled, scaly serpent with its head raised vertically, its mouth open with teeth along the lower jaw and tongue visible.

In the waves of a tumultuous sea, Leviathan appears. Blake inscribed another color-printed impression of the design alone "O revolving serpent / O the Ocean of Time & Space" (Essick collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman). The sky is reddish on the left (suggesting a sunrise or sunset), dark on the right.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 23, Object 7 (Bentley 136.7, Butlin 260.7)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a dark, mountainous landscape opening onto an area of blue-purple sky, a fully gowned male with long, flowing beard, probably Urizen, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm extends forward with the palm of the hand vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe that emits spiky beams of light. At bottom right the head and front leg of a lion appear in profile. The illustration seems to depict the episode in which "Urizen explor'd his dens / Mountain, moor, & wilderness, / With a globe of fire lighting his / journey" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 22, Erdman page 81). Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design alone "Fearless tho in pain / I travel on" (private collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: Urizen, as a fully gowned male with long, flowing beard, strides vigorously to the right. His left arm is extended with his palm vertical. With his right hand by his side he holds a sun-like globe. His eyes appear to be looking down, possibly at the lion.
A dark, mountainous landscape opens onto an area of blue-purple sky.
A dark, mountainous landscape opens onto an area of blue-purple sky.
The head and front leg of a lion with long mane appear in profile.
With his right hand by his side Urizen holds a sun-like globe that emits spiky beams of light. Like a lamp, the globe may be lighting Urizen's way in the darkness.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 24, Object 8 (Bentley 136.8, Butlin 260.8)

objnote.p: In this impression, Blake printed only the lower third of this full-page design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A human figure lower left, probably representing one of the first four sons of Urizen, inhabits a compartmented landscape of sea and sky. This is probably Utha, who emerges "from the waters" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 23, Erdman page 81) and looks upward.

component.illusobjdesc: A line of cloud (or a mountain ridge) divides the plate into areas of what may be dark clouds, sky or mountains to the left, red clouds possibly representing a sunrise or a sunset to the right, a golden sky, and dark sea below. The scene is stormy.
The head of Utha emerges from waves of dark water.

The upward-looking head of a long-haired figure of uncertain sex, but apparently male, emerges from the water. He seems to be one of the first sons of Urizen, Utha, who emerges "from the waters" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 23, Erdman page 81). He represents the classical element water in *The First Book of Urizen*, the illuminated book from which this design derives.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 3, Object 9 (Bentley 136.9, Butlin 260.9)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "14a," not by Blake. Another color printed impression of the design along is inscribed on the verso, not by Blake, "Oh! Flames of Furious Desires" (Butlin no. 261.4).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short bushy hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread. Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, his entire body.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude young man—variously identified as Los, Orc, and Urizen—with short bushy hair, facing away from the viewer, runs right to left with his arms outstretched and legs spread. The palms of his raised hands face downward; his feet are prominent.
Flames envelop, and perhaps emanate from, the figure's entire body.

desc.objtitle: The Book of Thel, Plate 2 (title page), Object 10 (Bentley 136.10, Butlin 260.10)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel, wearing a long gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands left by a tree trunk and gazes at a nude man embracing a woman around the waist. The latter wears a gown and raises her arms. These small figures seem to emerge from the large, bowl-like flowers. The leaves of this plant and a flower bud complete the design. The figures above the flowers may suggest the "raptures" (Book of Thel, Plate 5, line 13) of the Cloud and the "fair eyed dew" (*The Book of Thel*, Bentley Plate 5, Erdman Plate 3 page 5) during their courtship.

component.illusobjdesc: Thel stands by and perhaps leans on a large tree trunk along the left margin.

Two open flowers and one bud bloom from the slender, arching stems of a plant. These flowers may be the pasqueflower (anemone pulsatilla). They seem to be blown to the left by a gentle wind. The plant's large leaves bend to the ground. Three stems bearing spiky leaves, or the remnants of blossoms, or perhaps grain tassels also grow from the plant. The purple form in the background sky may be a cloud at sunrise or sunset.

Thel, wearing a gown and holding a shepherd's crook, stands in a delicate contrapposto posture and looks upon the figures and flowers on the right. Her long hair cascades down her neck, touching both shoulders; the hem of her gown curls about her feet and over the ground.

A youthful female hovers to the left of an open flower. She wears a gown with a ruffled hem. She raises both arms above her head, palms turned up and out with fingers spread, as a nude male embraces her waist. Her legs are spread apart as though she were striding to the left; she may be fleeing from the male. Strands of her long hair can be seen left of her right arm. Her body faces forward, but her head is turned to the right, possibly to look at the male.

A nude, apparently youthful, man hovers to the left of an open flower and embraces a young woman around her waist with at least his left arm and hand. His legs are spread apart; his hair appears to be long. He may be gazing toward the female.
The purple form in the background sky, upper right, may be a cloud at sunrise or sunset.
Color printing just above the lower margin of the design suggests vegetation, possibly grass, moss, or lichens..

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 27, Object 11 (Bentley 136.11, Butlin 260.11)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object. The rounded shapes upper left and right of the figure may be stones or clouds.

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned male, perhaps Urizen, hovers or perhaps strides with his face away from the viewer and his right foot trailing visibly below his gown. He holds his hands, palms vertical and fingers spread, beside his face as if looking through an opening or pushing against an object. His long (or at least medium length) hair extends in slightly spiky locks on each side of his head.
The rounded object left of the figure's left arm and above his head may be a cloud or large stone. Another such cloud or stone appears to the right of the figure's right arm and hip.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 2, Object 12 (Bentley 136.12, Butlin 260.12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young woman wearing a full gown floats horizontally in the clouded sky. The woman extends her slightly bent left arm parallel to the line of her legs to hold the arm of a naked infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown. Background coloring suggests the sky with clouds at sunrise or sunset. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design "Teach these Souls to Fly" (Butlin no. 261.5).

component.illusobjdesc: Drawn in left profile with her back to the viewer, a young female wearing a full, flowing gown hovers horizontally in a clouded sky. She extends her slightly bent left arm parallel to her legs to hold the arm of a nude infant who floats horizontally in line with her arm. Her right arm is apparently along the right side of her body and right hand seems to hold a fold in her gown. Her hair is long, perhaps arranged into some sort of coiffure. She appears to be looking at the infant; her right foot is prominent.

A nude infant, whose arm is held by a female, floats horizontally in line with her arm. Both arms are extended horizontally; the fingers of the left hand may be slightly spread. The infant's body faces to the right, but its head is turn toward the viewer.
A young female wearing a full, flowing gown hovers horizontally in a clouded sky. The reddened areas of the sky around and below the central figures suggest sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 8, Object 13 (Bentley 136.13, Butlin 260.13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A human skeleton, viewed from the side, sits in a severely contracted position with curved spine, head bowed, legs drawn up to head, and (the only visible) hand clutching the head. In the context of the gestation and birth metaphors of the text in *The First Book of Urizen*, the skeleton's position may suggest a fetus huddled in a womb.

component.illusobjdesc: A human skeleton, viewed from the side, sits in a severely contracted position with curved spine, head bowed, legs drawn up to head, and (the only visible) hand clutching the head. In the context of the gestation and birth metaphors of the text of *The First Book of Urizen*, the skeleton's position may suggest a fetus huddled in a womb.
The dark area surrounding the skeleton may simply be the sky at night or the inside of a cave. If however the figure is a fetus, then the surrounding space may be the interior of a womb.

desc.objtitle:
The First Book of Urizen, Plate 19,
Object 14 (Bentley 136.14, Butlin 260.14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: On the left a nude female with long hair stands or runs with her body arched and twisted sharply to the left, her right foot forward, and her hands raised to her head. On the ground beside her to the right sits a second nude figure, probably male, in a contracted position with his legs doubled up beneath him and his hands clutching his head. The two figures may be Los and Enitharmon: "the first female now separate / Pale as a cloud of snow / Waving before the face of Los" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 18, Erdman page 78). The light blue area behind the female might represent smoke, clouds or large stones. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design alone "Is the Female death / Become new Life" (private collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: On the left a nude female with long hair, perhaps Enitharmon, stands or runs with her body arched and twisted sharply to the left, her right foot forward, and her hands raised to her head. Her mouth appears to be slightly open; her facial expression suggests despair mixed with fear.
On the ground to the right sits a nude figure with curly hair, probably male, perhaps Los, in a contracted position with his legs doubled up beneath him and his hands clutching his head.
The light blue area behind the female might represent smoke, clouds, or large stones. The sky (?) is dark upper right.
Color printing below the kneeling figure hints at vegetation, possibly moss or lichens.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 10, Object 15 (Bentley 136.15, Butlin 260.15)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of stone. His left leg is placed forward and bent at the knee and his right leg extended behind, as if positioned to support the weight of the massive rock above. His arms, accordingly, are raised horizontally and bent upward at the elbows, in a position to support weight from above. His head and hands are hidden by the rock; alternatively he may be headless. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design alone "Does the Soul labour thus / In the Caverns of The Grave" (Butlin no. 261.6, Erdman page 673).

component.illusobjdesc: A muscular nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of rock. His left leg is placed forward and bent at the knee and his right leg extended behind, as if positioned to support the weight of the massive rock above. His arms, accordingly, are raised horizontally and bent upward at the elbows, in a position to support weight from above. His head and hands are hidden by the rock; alternatively he may be headless.

A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of rock. There may be three separate rocks arranged like a trilithon, with the upper horizontal supported by the two verticals on either side.

A nude man seen from behind stands in a cave-like opening in a wall of rock. There may be three separate rocks arranged like a trilithon, with the upper horizontal supported by the two verticals on either side.

desc.objtitle: The Book of Thel, Plate 6, Object 16 (Bentley 136.16, Butlin 260.16)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands center right, accompanied by the personified Cloud and Worm. Her arms, raised horizontally, imitate the gesture of the cloud, a nude male (except for a slip of drapery) hovering in the air. The hem of Thel's gown seems to be ruffled by the same breeze on which the Cloud floats. The Worm, portrayed as an infant, rests in a bed formed by a lily plant. Several flowers on a single stem are pictured just to the left of the infant Worm. A tree trunk and a spiraling vine dominate the right margin. Large clouds fill the sky right and left of Thel; blue coloring extending to the left margin suggest sky, with red areas of the clouds suggesting sunrise or sunset and perhaps a storm. The design would seem to illustrate the last two lines of verse on the plate previous to the corresponding plate and the first line of verse on the corresponding plate of the Book of Thel: "The helpless worm arose, and sat upon the Lillys leaf, / And the bright Cloud saild on, to find his partner in the vale. / . . . Then Thel astonish'd view'd the Worm upon its dewy bed" (*The Book of Thel*, Bentley Plates 5-6, Erdman Plates 3-4 page 5).

component.illusobjdesc: The trunk of a tree, perhaps a birch, is pictured along the right margin.
A vine spirals upward to the left of the tree trunk.

A large plant with spiky and arching leaves, probably a lily, forms a bed for the infant Worm. A long vine-like tendril trails to the left. A small cluster of flowers, perhaps St. Bernard's lilies, appears left of the Worm.
A few spiky lines indicate grass or a small plant to the left of the base of the tree trunk.

Thel stands with arms raised horizontally, as if imitating the Cloud's gestures, and looks down at the personified Worm. The hem of her gown flutters to the left, as though blown by a breeze, but her long hair seems blown to the right. She may be striding away from the viewer and to the left. Her feet, left foot forward, are bare; her right foot is on tiptoe. The fingers of her raised hands, palms out, are spread apart.

The personified Cloud hovers in the air, his arms raised horizontally and his legs apart, the left bent at the knee. He is basically nude, but a flag-like piece of drapery trails behind him. He may be holding one end of this drapery in his left hand. His long hair floats to the right. His body faces forward and to the left, but her turns his head back to the right.
The personified Worm, a nude infant boy, lies among the leaves of a lily plant. He may be looking up and to the right, towards Thel. His legs are together and his arms are at his side.

Coloring in the sky left and right of Thel delineate one or more large clouds. Blue coloring extending to the left margin suggest sky, with red areas of the clouds suggesting sunrise or sunset and perhaps a storm.

The hem of Thel's gown and the posture of the personified Cloud suggest a wind blowing from right to left. However, the position of these characters' long hair suggests a breeze in the opposite direction.

desc.objtitle: Visions of the Daughters of Albion, Plate 10, Object 17 (Bentley 136.17, Butlin 260.17)

objnote.p: Inscribed on the verso, "10a," not by Blake.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Four (possibly five) female figures huddle together in contracted postures. The four clearly pictured wear gowns. The figure on the right squats with knees drawn up toward her chest; her head leans forward onto her knees and we see only the top of her head. Her hair is long. The figure in the center foreground faces to the right, with her knees drawn up and her upper body leaning forward. Her right knee and lower leg cover her face; we see only her head and long hair. Above this central figure and slightly behind are the shoulders and face of a woman with long hair (spread out on both sides of her head) and a desperate expression on her face. Her hands are raised to her shoulders with palms turned upward. Her eyes look up. The left-most figure faces left. Her upper body is bent over her legs in a severely contracted posture. Her head is on the far left, bent low over her extended left arm. Above this figure is an indeterminate cluster of wavy lines that may be the hair of a fifth female figure. These females are probably the Daughters of Albion. A low hill appears on the left. There are clouds in the sky, with perhaps a sunrise or sunset. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design along "Wait Sisters / Tho all is Lost" (Butlin no. 261.7, Erdman page 673).

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned female in a very contracted posture squats on the ground far right. Her large knees are drawn up to her chest; her head is bent forward and rests on her knees. We see only the top of her head and long blonde hair. She is probably one of the Daughters of Albion in this huddled group of four or five females.

A gowned female sits in a contracted posture as the front-most figure in the huddled group. She faces to the right, with her right knee drawn up and her upper body bent forward. Her face is covered by her right knee and lower leg; we see only her head and long, dark hair. She is probably one of the Daughters of Albion in this group of four or five figures.

Behind two other figures, we see the shoulders, hands, and face of a gowned female. Her long hair extends horizontally on either side of her head. Her face and eyes are turned upward; her facial expression suggests despair. Her hands are raised to her shoulders, palms turned upward. She is probably one of the Daughters of Albion, sitting with others in this huddled group.

On the far left of the huddled group of figures is a gowned female with her upper body bent over her legs in an extremely contracted posture. She faces to the left, with her head bent down and resting on her left arm. Her left arm, and particularly her left hand, dangle to the left. Her hair may be curly. She is probably one of the Daughters of Albion.

A few wavy lines, just above the left-most figure in this huddled group of figures, may be the lowered head, curly(?) hair, and shoulders of a fifth female. She is probably one of the Daughters of Albion, like the others in this group. She is probably gowned.
The setting for the huddled figures consists of a dark (and stormy?) sky filled with clouds, including red clouds that suggest a sunrise or sunset.
A low hill appears on the left.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 7, Object 18 (Bentley 136.18, Butlin 260.18)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude man, perhaps Los, kneels in flames that swirl about him as he clutches his head with crossed arms and hands, right hand to left side of face, left hand to right side. His mouth and eyes are wide open as if in agony or terror, perhaps depicting the moment when "Los howld in a dismal stupor" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 7, Erdman page 74). Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design alone, "I sought Pleasure & found Pain / Unutterable" (private collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude man, perhaps Los, kneels in flames that swirl about him as he clutches his head with crossed arms and hands, right hand to left side of face, left hand to right side. His mouth and eyes are wide open as if in agony or terror. Perhaps we can see his tongue inside his mouth. His hair is flame-like and his left foot is prominent.
Swirling flames surround a male figure, perhaps Los.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 11, Object 19 (Bentley 136.19, Butlin 260.19)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two nude male figures, with tormented expressions and their legs drawn up toward their chests, sit in or in front of a wall of upward-swirling flames (left) and a dome (right). The emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure on the left looks upward while holding his arms at his sides and resting his hands on his knees. The figure on the right sits with head tilted back and his right shoulder twisted around to allow both hands to rest on the ground on one side. If the figure on the right is Los, the round object at bottom right is probably one end of the "great hammer" that "fell from his hand" when he "shrunk from his task" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 13, Erdman page 77) after putting Urizen in chains. The figure on the left is shackled and chained around the ankles and thus may be Urizen. Just left of the background dome (St. Paul's of London or St. Peter's in Rome?) is a pillar or tower leaning to the left, perhaps based on the famous leaning tower of Pisa. Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design alone "Every thing is an attempt / To be Human" (private collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude male with tormented, pained expression and legs drawn up toward his chest sits in or near a wall of upward-swirling flames. His body faces forward but his head is bent back and he faces up and to the right. The emaciated, virtually skeletal, figure looks upward, mouth slightly open, while holding his arms at his sides and resting his hands on his knees. He is shackled and chained at the ankles. He may be Urizen after being enchained by Los.

A nude male, perhaps Los, with tormented or pained expression and legs drawn up toward his chest sits before a dome and leaning column or tower. His head is tilted back and his right shoulder twisted around to allow both hands to rest on the ground on one side, where a hammer rests. His hair is flame-like.
The figure on the left is shackled and chained around the ankles. The chains are connected to large rings or links just above the lower margin of the plate.
The figure on the left sits within or in front of upward-swirling flames that extend upward and to the right above the other figure.
Behind the figure on the right is a dome (St. Paul's of London or St. Peter's in Rome?) and a pillar or tower leaning to the left, perhaps based on the famous leaning tower of Pisa.
If the nude figure on the right is Los, the object in the lower right corner is probably the end of his hammer resting on the ground.

desc.objtitle: Visions of the Daughters of Albion, Plate 3, Object 20 (Bentley 136.20, Butlin 260.20)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young nude woman kneels on the ground and leans to the right with her arms crossed in front of her and her hands over her breasts. Her hair appears to be drawn back in a bun, yet a few strands of long hair curl down her back. She might be kissing a much smaller figure, probably also female. The second nude figure is seen from behind; her arms are extended horizontally. Her right foot is poised just above one of the two flowers, probably marigolds, growing on a plant lower right. Her left leg is bent at the knee in a dance-like posture. She seems to hover in the air. The kneeling figure is probably Oothoon, the smaller figure probably the "nymph" who personifies the marigold. As the text on Plate 4 explains, "Oothoon wanderd in woe, / Along the vales of Leutha seeking flowers to comfort her; / And thus she spoke to the bright Marygold of Leutha's vale / Art thou a flower! art thou a nymph! I see thee now a flower; / Now a nymph!" (*Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 4, Erdman Plate 1 pages 45-46). Given this textual point of contact, the landscape is Leutha's Vale, also named in the text. The hovering nymph may also be identified with Leutha—see "Leutha's flower" (*Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 3, Erdman plate iii page 45). The earth on which the figure kneels is colored as though covered with grass, moss, or lichens. Bursts of radiance fill the sky; they would seem to emanate from a sun just below the horizon on the right. A beam of light may be emanating from the marigold furthest to the right.

component.illusobjdesc: A young nude woman kneels on the ground and leans to the right with her arms crossed in front of her and her hands over her breasts. Her hair appears to be drawn back in a bun, yet a few strands of long hair curl down her back. She might be kissing a much smaller figure, probably also female. Given the text on the corresponding and next plate, she is almost certainly Oothoon.

A nude figure, probably female, is seen from behind. Her hair appears to be short. She hovers in the air, with her right foot poised just above a flower from which she may be rising. Her arms are extended horizontally, raised hands with palms down, and her left knee is bent forward. This dance-like posture includes a gracefully twisted torso. Her head may be bent back and she might be kissing the much larger female on the left. Given the textual parallels for the design, this small figure is probably the "nymph" who personifies the marigold flower below her (*Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 4, Erdman Plate 1 page 46). She may also be identified with Leutha—see "Leutha's flower" (*Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 3, Erdman plate iii page 45).

A low-growing plant appears lower right in the landscape. Two arching stems terminate in large flowers—probably the marigolds noted in the text on Plate 4. Their petals are spiky or flame-like. These may be "Leutha's flower[s]" (*Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 3, Erdman plate iii pages 45-46).

The ground on which the figure kneels is colored as though covered with grass, moss, or lichens. This is probably part of "Leutha's vale" (*Visions of the Daughters of Albion*, Bentley Plate 4, Erdman Plate 1 page 45).
Large shafts of light fill the sky. Most of the light seems to emanate from a rising or setting sun just below the horizon on the right, but one ray may emerge from the flower also lower right.

desc.objtitle: The First Book of Urizen, Plate 5, Object 21 (Bentley 136.21, Butlin 260.21)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer squarely. Spiky beams of light radiate above his head. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks. Red flames appear above he figure's head and wrap around his left arm. The design may depict the moment when the Eternals "saw his pale visage / Emerge from the darkness; his hand / . . . unclasping / The Book of brass" (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 4, Erdman page 72). Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design along "The Book of my Remembrance" (Butlin no. 261.8, Erdman page 673).

component.illusobjdesc: A fully gowned old man with long white hair and beard, presumably Urizen, faces the viewer directly. Spiky beams of light radiate above his head. From a sitting or squatting position, with arms raised horizontally, he holds the top corners of a large book. He would appear to be looking down at the book. His right leg is bent at the knee and drawn up toward his chest.
Urizen holds the top corners of a large book, perhaps the Book of Brass (*The First Book of Urizen* Plate 4), that opens toward the viewer, revealing a text of indecipherable marks.
Red flames appear above the figure's head and wrap around his left arm.

desc.objtitle: The Book of Thel, Plate 7, Object 22 (Bentley 136.22, Butlin 260.22)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel sits on the ground, arms folded, and looks at the personified Worm and Clod (or "matron Clay" [*The Book of Thel*, Bentley Plate 7, Erdman Plate 5 page 6]). Her long hair cascades over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown billows around her. The infant Worm extends both arms and looks at the Clod, a young, nude woman lying on the ground. Right of Thel is a large plant with arching and spiky leaves and two blossoms, one of which dangles over Thel's head. Left of Thel is another plant with similar leaves but no blossoms. Mountains dominate the background to the left of Thel; the sky upper right may be cloudy and colored to suggest a sunrise or sunset. The design may in part illustrate lines on the previous plate in *The Book of Thel*: "The Clod of Clay heard the Worms voice, & raisd her pitying head; / She bow'd over the weeping infant..." (Bentley Plate 6, Erdman Plate 4 page 5). Blake inscribed another color printed impression of the design alone "Doth God take Care of these" (private collection, not recorded in Butlin or Erdman).

component.illusobjdesc: A large plant with arching, spiky leaves grows on the right. One of its two flowers dangles above Thel's head. Long stamens descend from the blossom on the right; the blossom on the left is less open and may be only a bud. The plant may be a combination of the flowers of the Meadia or dodecatheon, the golden amaryllis, and the leaves of the St. Bernard's lily.
A large plant with arching, spiky leaves rises to the left of Thel. This may be the colorless monotropa or corpse-plant.
Two stems of a plant grow just left of Thel's waist.

Thel sits on the ground, her arms folded over her chest and knees in a contracted position. Her long hair falls over her shoulders; the hem of her long gown cascades around her. She may be looking down at the personified Clod and Worm with head bowed.

The nude, infant Worm lies on the ground with legs crossed and arms extended at an angle of 135 degrees. His left hand is raised, palm up. His head is turned toward the Clod; he may be looking at her.

The personified Clod or "matron Clay" (*The Book of Thel*, Bentley Plate 7, Erdman Plate 5 page 6) lies on the ground. She may be reaching towqrd the personified Worm with her right arm. She is a nude young woman with long hair.
The peaks of two mountains dominate the sky behind and to the left of Thel. The coloring above Thel and to the right of the mountains suggests clouds a sunrise or sunset.

desc.objtitle: The Book of Thel, Plate 4, Object 23 (Bentley 136.23, Butlin 260.23)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Thel stands beneath the branches of a tree, perhaps a birch or willow. She bows slightly toward the personified Lilly who, with arms folded, bows more deeply toward Thel. Both females wear long gowns, ruffled along the hems. A vine climbs lazily about the tree trunk. This vine seems to grow from the plant right of Thel. The plant behind and to the right of the Lilly is probably a lily, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily. The design illustrates the dialogue between Thel and the Lilly given in the text on this plate in *The Book of Thel*. The moment pictured may be their parting, when "the Lilly bowd her modest head" (*The Book of Thel*, Bentley Plate 4, Erdman Plate 2 page 4).

component.illusobjdesc: The branches of a tree form a canopy over the figures. It may be a birch or willow. Small leaves dangle from the smaller branches on the left.
A plant grows between Thel and the tree and right of the tree. Vine-like stems curl upwards from this plant.
A large lily plant, perhaps the St. Bernard's lily, blooms behind and to the right of the personified Lilly. It bears several flowering stems.

Thel, wearing a long gown with a ruffled hem, stands with her arms at her side in a slightly bowed posture, facing to the left and probably looking at the Lilly. Her long hair falls over her shoulders. Her feet (right foot forward) are bare.

The personified Lilly bows, with arms apparently folded, toward Thel. The hem of the Lilly's gown is elaborately ruffled. She faces down and to the right. She appears to be hovering slightly above the ground.
Dark clouds behind the Lilly and to the left suggest a storm. The red coloring behind Thel and to the right suggest a sunrise or a sunset.
The color printing just above the bottom margin of the design hints at vegetation, possibly grass, moss, or lichens.
